key_title: Key to the genera of Scrophulariaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Barker, W.R.
source.title: Scrophulariaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Barker, W.R. (1999). Scrophulariaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Shrubs (sometimes prostrate) to small trees; stamens 4
Herbs or, if shrubby then stamens 2
Plants with stellate hairs on at least new growth; leaves opposite; inflorescence cymose, many-flowered, terminal and/or axillary
Plants glabrous or simple-haired; leaves alternate (sometimes sub-opposite); inflorescence axillary, 1–few-flowered
Corolla rotate, actinomorphic, white or tinged violet or pink, usually spotted in throat, tube <6 mm long
Corolla at least slightly zygomorphic, variously coloured, rarely white, tube >8 mm long
Dehisced anthers reniform
Dehisced anthers sagittate, the two portions not fully coalescing but joined by a narrow connective at apex
Leaves all radical; plants lacking obvious stems (rarely stolons produced, then leaves opposite); flowers small, regular or almost so; aquatic or semi-aquatic annuals (rarely perennials)
At least some leaves cauline; plants with obvious stems; flowers regular or bilabiate; mostly land plants (some Veronica more or less aquatic)
Sepals free for more than half their length; perennial subshrubs with 2-lipped corollas or biennial herbs with rotate corollas
Sepals fused for more than half their length; annual herbs, corollas with long, slender tubes and 5 short, equal, spreading lobes
Leaves opposite or whorled
Leaves alternate, at least in upper parts
Corolla tube urceolate or globose, about as wide as long; style decurved against lobes of lower lip of corolla
Corolla tube conical, much longer than wide; style erect
[link through]
[link through]
Corolla small (2–5 mm diam.), white; perennial subshrub; inflorescences corymbs of numerous compact spikes
Corolla at least 15 mm diam., mostly yellow or pink (rarely white) usually with a contrasting central colour; rosetted biennials; inflorescences long-racemose or spicate
